# 2010 FIFA World Cup

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

"FIFA 2010" redirects here. For the video game, see [FIFA 10](/wiki/FIFA_10
"FIFA 10").

This article is about 2010 FIFA World Cup. For the video game, see [2010 FIFA
World Cup South Africa (video
game)](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_South_Africa_\(video_game\) "2010 FIFA World
Cup South Africa \(video game\)"). For other uses, see [2010 World Cup
(disambiguation)](/wiki/2010_World_Cup_\(disambiguation\) "2010 World Cup
\(disambiguation\)").

The **2010 FIFA World Cup** was the 19th [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup
"FIFA World Cup"), the world championship for [men's
national](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams "List of
men's national association football teams") [association
football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") teams. It took
place in [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") from 11 June to 11
July 2010. The [bidding
process](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts#2010_FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup
hosts") for hosting the tournament finals was open only to African nations. In
2004, the international football federation, [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA"),
selected South Africa over Egypt and Morocco to become the first African
nation to host the finals.[6]

The matches were played in 10 stadiums in nine host cities around the
country,[7] with the opening and final played at the [Soccer
City](/wiki/Soccer_City "Soccer City") stadium in South Africa's largest city,
[Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg").[8][9] Thirty-two teams were
selected for participation[10] via a [worldwide qualification
tournament](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "2010 FIFA World Cup
qualification") that began in August 2007. In the first round of the
tournament finals, the teams competed in [round-robin](/wiki/Round-
robin_tournament "Round-robin tournament") groups of four teams for points,
with the top two teams in each group proceeding. These 16 teams advanced to
the [knockout stage](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "2010 FIFA World
Cup knockout stage"), where three rounds of play decided which teams would
participate in the [final](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2010 FIFA World
Cup Final").

In the final, [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team"), the [European champions](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008 "UEFA Euro
2008"), defeated the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team
"Netherlands national football team") (third-time losing finalists) 1–0 [after
extra time](/wiki/After_extra_time "After extra time"), with [Andrés
Iniesta](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta "Andrés Iniesta")'s goal in the 116th
minute giving Spain their first world title. Spain became the eighth nation to
win the tournament and the first European nation to win a World Cup hosted
outside its home continent: all previous World Cups held outside Europe had
been won by South American nations. They are also the only national team since
[1978](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup") to win a World Cup
after losing a game in the group stage. As a result of their win, Spain
represented the World in the [2013 FIFA Confederations
Cup](/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup "2013 FIFA Confederations Cup"). Host
nation [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa_national_football_team "South Africa
national football team"), [2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World
Cup") champions [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national
football team") and 2006 runners-up
[France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team")
were all eliminated in the first round of the tournament. It was the first
time that the hosts had been eliminated in the first round. [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_national_football_team "New Zealand national
football team"), with their three draws, were the only undefeated team in the
tournament, but they were also eliminated in the first round.

## Host selection

Main article: [FIFA World Cup hosts § 2010 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts#2010_FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup hosts")

Africa was chosen as the host for the 2010 World Cup as part of a short-lived
rotation policy, abandoned in 2007,[11] to rotate the event among football
confederations. Five African nations placed bids to host the 2010 World Cup:
Egypt, Morocco, South Africa and a joint bid from Libya and Tunisia.

Following the decision of the FIFA Executive Committee not to allow co-hosted
tournaments, Tunisia withdrew from the bidding process. The committee also
decided not to consider Libya's solo bid as it no longer met all the
stipulations laid down in the official _List of Requirements_.

The winning bid was announced by FIFA president [Sepp
Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter") at a media conference on 15 May
2004 in [Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"); in the first round of voting,
South Africa received 14 votes, Morocco received 10 votes and Egypt no votes.
South Africa, which had narrowly [failed to win the right to host the 2006
event](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup#Host_selection "2006 FIFA World Cup"), was
thus awarded the right to host the tournament.[12] Having successfully
campaigned for South Africa to be granted host status, an emotional [Nelson
Mandela](/wiki/Nelson_Mandela "Nelson Mandela") raised the [FIFA World Cup
Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy "FIFA World Cup Trophy").[13]

During 2006 and 2007, rumours circulated in various news sources that the 2010
World Cup could be moved to another country.[14][15] [Franz
Beckenbauer](/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer "Franz Beckenbauer"), [Horst R.
Schmidt](/wiki/Horst_R._Schmidt "Horst R. Schmidt") and, reportedly, some
[FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") executives, expressed concern over the planning,
organisation, and pace of South Africa's preparations.[14][16] FIFA officials
repeatedly expressed their confidence in South Africa as host, stating that a
contingency plan existed only to cover natural catastrophes, as had been in
place at previous FIFA World Cups.[17]

### Bribery and corruption

On 28 May 2015, media covering the [2015 FIFA corruption
case](/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case "2015 FIFA corruption case") reported
that high-ranking officials from the South African bid committee had secured
the right to host the World Cup by paying US $10 million in bribes to then-
FIFA Vice President [Jack Warner](/wiki/Jack_Warner_\(football_executive\)
"Jack Warner \(football executive\)") and to other FIFA Executive Committee
members.[18]

On 4 June 2015, FIFA executive [Chuck Blazer](/wiki/Chuck_Blazer "Chuck
Blazer"), having co-operated with the [FBI](/wiki/FBI "FBI") and the Swiss
authorities, confirmed that he and the other members of FIFA's executive
committee were bribed in order to promote the South African 1998 and 2010
World Cup bids. Blazer stated, "I and others on the Fifa executive committee
agreed to accept bribes in conjunction with the selection of South Africa as
the host nation for the 2010 World Cup."[19][20]

On 6 June 2015, _[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily
Telegraph")_ reported that [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco") had actually won
the vote, but [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") was awarded
the tournament instead.[21]

## Qualification

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup
qualification](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "2010 FIFA World Cup
qualification")

The qualification draw for the 2010 World Cup was held in
[Durban](/wiki/Durban "Durban") on 25 November 2007. As the host nation,
[South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa_national_football_team "South Africa
national football team") qualified automatically for the tournament. As
happened in the [previous tournament](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA
World Cup"), the defending champions were not given an automatic berth, and
[Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team") had
to participate in qualification. With a pool of entrants comprising 204 of the
208 [FIFA national
teams](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams "List of
men's national association football teams") at the time, the 2010 World Cup
shares with the [2008 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer
Olympics") the record for most competing nations in a sporting event.

Some controversies arose during the qualifications. In the second leg of the
[play-off between France and the Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/2009_Republic_of_Ireland_v_France_football_matches "2009
Republic of Ireland v France football matches"), French captain [Thierry
Henry](/wiki/Thierry_Henry "Thierry Henry"), unseen by the referee, handled
the ball in the lead up to a late goal, which enabled France to qualify ahead
of Ireland, sparking widespread comment and debate. FIFA rejected a request
from the [Football Association of
Ireland](/wiki/Football_Association_of_Ireland "Football Association of
Ireland") to replay the match,[22] and Ireland later withdrew a request to be
included as an unprecedented 33rd World Cup entrant.[23][24] As a result, FIFA
announced a review into the use of technology or extra officials at the
highest level, but decided against the widely expected fast-tracking of goal-
line referee's assistants for the South African tournament.[25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg/220px-
Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Watching_South_Africa_%26_Mexico_match_at_World_Cup_2010-06-11_in_Soweto_7.jpg
"Enlarge")

Supporters watching the 2010 FIFA World Cup in South Africa, with
[vuvuzelas](/wiki/Vuvuzela "Vuvuzela").

[Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national
football team") complained over [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team
"Uruguay national football team")'s winning goal in the [CONMEBOL–CONCACAF
playoff](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(inter-confederation_play-
offs\)#CONCACAF_4th_place_v_CONMEBOL_5th_place "2010 FIFA World Cup
qualification \(inter-confederation play-offs\)"),[26] while Egypt and
Algeria's [November 2009 matches](/wiki/2009_Egypt_v_Algeria_football_matches
"2009 Egypt v Algeria football matches") were surrounded by reports of crowd
trouble. On the subject of fair play, FIFA President Sepp Blatter said:

> I appeal to all the players and coaches to observe this fair play. In 2010
> we want to prove that football is more than just kicking a ball but has
> social and cultural value ... So we ask the players 'please observe fair
> play' so they will be an example to the rest of the world.[27]

Slovakia was making its first appearance as an independent nation but had
previously been represented as part of the Czechoslovakia team that had last
played in the 1990 tournament; North Korea qualified for the first time since
1966; Honduras and New Zealand were both making their first appearances since
1982; and Algeria were at the finals for the first time since the 1986
competition.

Teams that failed to qualify for this tournament included [Saudi
Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia_national_football_team "Saudi Arabia national
football team"), which had qualified for the previous four tourmanents;
[Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia_national_football_team "Tunisia national football
team") and [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia national
football team"), both of whom had qualified for the previous three finals;
[Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national
football team"), [Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador_national_football_team "Ecuador
national football team"), [Poland](/wiki/Poland_national_football_team "Poland
national football team") and [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team
"Sweden national football team"), who had qualified for the previous two
editions; 2006 quarter-finalists
[Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team "Ukraine national football
team") and [Euro 2008](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008 "UEFA Euro 2008") semi-finalists
[Russia](/wiki/Russia_national_football_team "Russia national football team")
and [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey_national_football_team "Turkey national football
team").

As of 2018, this was the last time South Africa, New Zealand, North Korea,
Paraguay, Slovakia and Slovenia qualified for a FIFA World Cup finals.

## Preparations

Five new stadiums were built for the tournament, and five of the existing
venues were upgraded. Construction costs were expected to be
[R](/wiki/South_African_rand "South African rand")8.4 billion (just over US$1
billion or €950 million).[29]

South Africa also improved its public transport infrastructure within the host
cities, including Johannesburg's [Gautrain](/wiki/Gautrain "Gautrain") and
other metro systems, and major road networks were improved.[30] In March 2009,
[Danny Jordaan](/wiki/Danny_Jordaan "Danny Jordaan"), the president of the
2010 World Cup organising committee, reported that all stadiums for the
tournament were on schedule to be completed within six months.[31]

The country implemented special measures to ensure the safety and security of
spectators in accordance with standard FIFA requirements,[32] including a
temporary restriction of flight operation in the airspace surrounding the
stadiums.[33]

At a ceremony to mark 100 days before the event, FIFA president Sepp Blatter
praised the readiness of the country for the event.[34]

### Construction strike

On 8 July 2009, 70,000 construction workers[35] who were working on the new
stadiums walked off their jobs.[36] The majority of the workers receive
[R](/wiki/South_African_rand "South African rand")2500 per month (about
[£](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling")192, €224 or US$313), but the unions
alleged that some workers were grossly underpaid. A spokesperson for the
[National Union of
Mineworkers](/wiki/National_Union_of_Mineworkers_\(South_Africa\) "National
Union of Mineworkers \(South Africa\)") said to the
[SABC](/wiki/South_African_Broadcasting_Corporation "South African
Broadcasting Corporation") that the "no work no pay" strike would go on until
FIFA assessed penalties on the organisers. Other unions threatened to strike
into 2011.[37][38] The strike was swiftly resolved and workers were back at
work within a week of it starting. There were no further strikes and all
stadiums and construction projects were completed in time for the kick
off.[39]

## Prize money

The total prize money on offer for the tournament was confirmed by FIFA as
US$420 million (including payments of US$40 million to domestic clubs), a 60
percent increase on the 2006 tournament.[40] Before the tournament, each of
the 32 entrants received US$1 million for preparation costs. Once at the
tournament, the prize money was distributed as follows:[40]

  * US$8 million – To each team eliminated at the group stage (16 teams) ($8.98 million in 2018 US dollars[41])
  * US$9 million – To each team eliminated in the round of 16 (8 teams) ($10.10 million in 2018 US dollars[41])
  * US$14 million – To each team eliminated in the quarter-finals (4 teams) ($15.71 million in 2018 US dollars[41])
  * US$18 million – Fourth placed team ($20.20 million in 2018 US dollars[41])
  * US$20 million – Third placed team ($22.44 million in 2018 US dollars[41])
  * US$24 million – Runner up ($26.93 million in 2018 US dollars[41])
  * US$30 million – Winner ($33.67 million in 2018 US dollars[41])

In a first for the World Cup, FIFA made payments to the domestic clubs of the
players representing their national teams at the tournament. This saw a total
of US$40 million paid to domestic clubs. This was the result of an agreement
reached in 2008 between FIFA and European clubs to disband the
[G-14](/wiki/G-14 "G-14") group and drop their claims for compensation dating
back to 2005 over the financial cost of injuries sustained to their players
while on international duty, such as that from Belgian club [Charleroi
S.C.](/wiki/R._Charleroi_S.C. "R. Charleroi S.C.") for injury to Morocco's
[Abdelmajid Oulmers](/wiki/Abdelmajid_Oulmers "Abdelmajid Oulmers") in a
friendly game in 2004, and from English club [Newcastle
United](/wiki/Newcastle_United_F.C. "Newcastle United F.C.") for an injury to
England's [Michael Owen](/wiki/Michael_Owen "Michael Owen") in the [2006 World
Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup").[42][43][44]

## Venues

**Download coordinates as:**
[KML](//tools.wmflabs.org/kmlexport?article=2010_FIFA_World_Cup) **·**
[GPX](http://tripgang.com/kml2gpx/http%3A%2F%2Ftools.wmflabs.org%2Fkmlexport%3Farticle%3D2010_FIFA_World_Cup?gpx=1)  
  
In 2005, the organisers released a provisional list of 13 venues to be used
for the World Cup: [Bloemfontein](/wiki/Bloemfontein "Bloemfontein"), [Cape
Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), [Durban](/wiki/Durban "Durban"),
[Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg") (two venues),
[Kimberley](/wiki/Kimberley,_Northern_Cape "Kimberley, Northern Cape"),
[Klerksdorp](/wiki/Klerksdorp "Klerksdorp"), [Nelspruit](/wiki/Nelspruit
"Nelspruit"), [Orkney](/wiki/Orkney,_North_West "Orkney, North West"),
[Polokwane](/wiki/Polokwane "Polokwane"), [Port
Elizabeth](/wiki/Port_Elizabeth "Port Elizabeth"), [Pretoria](/wiki/Pretoria
"Pretoria"), and [Rustenburg](/wiki/Rustenburg "Rustenburg"). This was
narrowed down to the ten venues[45] that were officially announced by FIFA on
17 March 2006.

The altitude of several venues affected the motion of the ball[46] and player
performance,[47][48] although FIFA's medical chief downplayed this
consideration.[49] Six of the ten venues were over 1200m above sea level, with
the two Johannesburg venues – the [FNB Stadium](/wiki/FNB_Stadium "FNB
Stadium") (also known as Soccer City) and [Ellis Park
Stadium](/wiki/Ellis_Park_Stadium "Ellis Park Stadium") – the highest at
approximately 1750m.[50][51]

The FNB Stadium, the [Cape Town Stadium](/wiki/Cape_Town_Stadium "Cape Town
Stadium") and the [Nelson Mandela Bay
Stadium](/wiki/Nelson_Mandela_Bay_Stadium "Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium") in
Port Elizabeth were the most-used venues, each hosting eight matches. Ellis
Park Stadium and the [Moses Mabhida Stadium](/wiki/Moses_Mabhida_Stadium
"Moses Mabhida Stadium") in Durban hosted seven matches each, while the
[Loftus Versfeld Stadium](/wiki/Loftus_Versfeld_Stadium "Loftus Versfeld
Stadium") in Pretoria, the [Free State Stadium](/wiki/Free_State_Stadium "Free
State Stadium") in Bloemfontein and the [Royal Bafokeng
Stadium](/wiki/Royal_Bafokeng_Stadium "Royal Bafokeng Stadium") in Rustenburg
hosted six matches each. The [Peter Mokaba Stadium](/wiki/Peter_Mokaba_Stadium
"Peter Mokaba Stadium") in Polokwane and the [Mbombela
Stadium](/wiki/Mbombela_Stadium "Mbombela Stadium") in Nelspruit hosted four
matches each, but did not host any knockout-stage matches.

### Team base camps

The base camps are used by 32 national squads to stay and train before and
during the World Cup tournament. In February 2010, FIFA announced the base
camps for each participating team.[57] Fifteen teams were in [Gauteng
Province](/wiki/Gauteng_Province "Gauteng Province"), while six teams were
based in [KwaZulu-Natal](/wiki/KwaZulu-Natal "KwaZulu-Natal"), four in the
[Western Cape](/wiki/Western_Cape "Western Cape"), three in [North West
Province](/wiki/North_West_Province "North West Province") and one each in
[Mpumalanga](/wiki/Mpumalanga "Mpumalanga"), the [Eastern
Cape](/wiki/Eastern_Cape "Eastern Cape") and the [Northern
Cape](/wiki/Northern_Cape "Northern Cape").[58]

## Final draw

See also: [2010 FIFA World Cup seeding](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_seeding
"2010 FIFA World Cup seeding")

The FIFA Organising Committee approved the procedure for the final draw on 2
December 2009. The seeding was based on the October 2009 FIFA World Ranking
and seven squads joined hosts South Africa as seeded teams for the final draw.
No two teams from the same confederation were to be drawn in the same group,
except allowing a maximum of two European teams in a group.[59]

The group draw was staged in [Cape Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), South
Africa, on 4 December 2009 at the [Cape Town International Convention
Centre](/wiki/Cape_Town_International_Convention_Centre "Cape Town
International Convention Centre").[60] The ceremony was presented by South
African actress [Charlize Theron](/wiki/Charlize_Theron "Charlize Theron"),
assisted by FIFA Secretary General [Jérôme
Valcke](/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_Valcke "Jérôme Valcke").[61] The balls were
drawn by [English](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national
football team") football star [David Beckham](/wiki/David_Beckham "David
Beckham") and African sporting figures [Haile
Gebrselassie](/wiki/Haile_Gebrselassie "Haile Gebrselassie"), [John
Smit](/wiki/John_Smit "John Smit"), [Makhaya Ntini](/wiki/Makhaya_Ntini
"Makhaya Ntini"), [Matthew Booth](/wiki/Matthew_Booth_\(soccer\) "Matthew
Booth \(soccer\)") and Simphiwe Dludlu.[62]

## Referees

Main articles: [2010 FIFA World Cup
officials](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_officials "2010 FIFA World Cup
officials") and [2010 FIFA World Cup controversies §
Refereeing](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Refereeing "2010 FIFA
World Cup controversies")

FIFA's Referees' Committee selected 29
[referees](/wiki/Referee_\(association_football\) "Referee \(association
football\)") through its Refereeing Assistance Programme to officiate at the
World Cup: four from the [AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian
Football Confederation"), three from the
[CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football"), six from [CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL"), four from
[CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF"), two from the
[OFC](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football Confederation")
and ten from [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA").[63] English referee Howard Webb was
chosen to referee the final, making him the first person to referee both the
[UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League")
final and the World Cup final in the same year.[64]

## Squads

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg/220px-
FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_3.jpg "Enlarge")

The Brazilian and North Korean teams before their group stage match

Further information: [2010 FIFA World Cup
squads](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_squads "2010 FIFA World Cup squads")

As with the [2006 tournament](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_squads "2006 FIFA
World Cup squads"), each team's squad for the 2010 World Cup consisted of 23
players. Each participating national association had to confirm their final
23-player [squad](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_squads "2010 FIFA World Cup
squads") by 1 June 2010. Teams were permitted to make late replacements in the
event of serious injury, at any time up to 24 hours before their first
game.[65]

Of the 736 players participating in the tournament, over half played their
club football in five European domestic leagues; those in England (117
players), Germany (84), Italy (80), Spain (59) and France (46).[66] The
English, German and Italian squads were made up of entirely home based
players, while only Nigeria had no players from clubs in their own league. In
all, players from 52 national leagues entered the tournament. [FC
Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") of Spain was the club
contributing the most players to the tournament, with 13 players of their side
travelling, 7 with the Spanish team, while another 7 clubs contributed 10
players or more.

In another first for South Africa 2010, one squad included three siblings.
[Jerry](/wiki/Jerry_Palacios "Jerry Palacios"), [Johnny](/wiki/Johnny_Palacios
"Johnny Palacios") and [Wilson Palacios](/wiki/Wilson_Palacios "Wilson
Palacios") made history thanks to their inclusion in Honduras's 23-man
list.[67] Unusually, the game between
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team") and [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team "Ghana national football
team") had two brothers playing for opposite nations, with [Jérôme
Boateng](/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_Boateng "Jérôme Boateng") and [Kevin-Prince
Boateng](/wiki/Kevin-Prince_Boateng "Kevin-Prince Boateng") playing
respectively.

## Match summary

The 32 national teams involved in the tournament together played a total of 64
matches starting from the group stage matches and progressing to the knockout
stage matches, with teams eliminated through the various progressive stages.
Rest days were allocated during the various stages to allow players recovery
during the tournament. Preliminary events were also held in celebration of the
World Cup event.[68] All times listed in the table below are in [South African
Standard Time](/wiki/South_African_Standard_Time "South African Standard
Time") ([UTC+02](/wiki/UTC%2B02 "UTC+02")).

## Group stage

In the first round, or group stage, the 32 teams were divided into eight
groups of four, with each team playing the other three teams in their group
once. Teams were awarded three points for a win, one point for a draw and none
for a defeat. The top two teams in each group advanced to the round of 16.

The South American teams performed strongly, with all five advancing to the
round of 16 (four as group winners), and four further advancing to the
quarter-finals. However, only Uruguay advanced to the semi-finals.

Of the six African teams, only Ghana advanced to the round of 16. South Africa
became the first host nation in World Cup history to be eliminated in the
first round, despite beating France and drawing with Mexico, while Ghana and
Ivory Coast were the only other African teams to win a match. The overall
performance of the African teams, in the first World Cup to be hosted on the
continent, was judged as disappointing by observers such as Cameroon great
[Roger Milla](/wiki/Roger_Milla "Roger Milla").[72]

Only six out of the thirteen [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") teams advanced to the
round of 16, a record low since the introduction of this stage in 1986.
Nonetheless, the final was contested by two European teams.[67] In another
World Cup first, the two finalists from the preceding tournament, Italy and
France, were eliminated at the group stage, with Italy becoming the third
defending champions to be eliminated in the first round after Brazil in 1966
and France in 2002.[73] New Zealand, one of the lowest-ranked teams, surprised
many by drawing all three of their group matches, ending the tournament as the
only undefeated team.

Tie-breaking criteria

Teams were ranked on the following criteria:[74]

    1\. Greater number of points in all group matches
    2\. Goal difference in all group matches
    3\. Greater number of goals scored in all group matches
    4\. Greatest number of points in matches between tied teams
    5\. Goal difference in matches between tied teams
    6\. Greatest number of goals scored in matches between tied teams
    7\. Drawing of lots by the FIFA Organising Committee

## Knockout stage

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "2010 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage")

_All times listed are[South African Standard
Time](/wiki/South_African_Standard_Time "South African Standard Time")
([UTC+02](/wiki/UTC%2B02 "UTC+02"))_

The [knockout stage](/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament "Single-elimination
tournament") comprised the 16 teams that advanced from the group stage of the
tournament. There were four rounds of matches, with each round eliminating
half of the teams entering that round. The successive rounds were the round of
16, quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final. There was also a play-off to
decide third and fourth place. For each game in the knockout stage, any draw
at 90 minutes was followed by thirty minutes of [extra time](/wiki/Extra_time
"Extra time"); if scores were still level, there was a [penalty
shootout](/wiki/Penalty_shootout_\(association_football\) "Penalty shootout
\(association football\)") to determine who progressed to the next round.[75]

### Round of 16

In this round, each group winner (A-H) was paired against the runner-up from
another group.

  * South American teams again performed strongly in the round of 16, with four teams advancing to the quarter-finals including [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team") who defeated fellow South Americans [Chile](/wiki/Chile_national_football_team "Chile national football team").
  * England's 4–1 loss to Germany was their biggest ever margin of defeat at a World Cup finals.[76][77] It was also the first time that a World Cup finals match between these two traditional rivals had a decisive result in regulation time, their [three previous meetings](/wiki/England%E2%80%93Germany_football_rivalry "England–Germany football rivalry") all being tied at 90 minutes, with two settled in extra time and one in a penalty shootout.
  * Ghana defeated the United States to become the third African team to reach the last eight (after [Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football team") in [1990](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA World Cup") and [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal_national_football_team "Senegal national football team") in [2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup")), and the only African team to have achieved both a top 8 finish and a separate top 16 finish (in 2006).
  * Paraguay and Ghana reached the quarter-finals for the first time.

The round was marked by some [controversial referees'
decisions](/wiki/List_of_2010_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies "List of 2010 FIFA
World Cup controversies"), including:

  * A disallowed goal by [England in their 4–1 loss against Germany](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Germany_vs_England "2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage"), where the shot by [Frank Lampard](/wiki/Frank_Lampard "Frank Lampard") was seen to cross substantially over the goal line when shown on television broadcast replays.
  * An allowed goal by [Argentina in their 3–1 win over Mexico](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Argentina_vs_Mexico "2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage"), where Argentine striker [Carlos Tevez](/wiki/Carlos_Tevez "Carlos Tevez") was seen to be offside when shown on television broadcast replays, which were shown inside the stadium shortly after the incident.

FIFA President [Sepp Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter") took the
unusual step of apologising to England and Mexico for the decisions that went
against them, saying: "Yesterday I spoke to the two federations directly
concerned by referees' mistakes [...] I apologised to England and Mexico. The
English said thank you and accepted that you can win some and you lose some
and the Mexicans bowed their head and accepted it."[78] Blatter also promised
to re-open the discussion regarding devices which monitor possible goals and
make that information immediately available to match officials, saying: "We
will naturally take on board the discussion on technology and have the first
opportunity in July at the business meeting."[78] Blatter's call came less
than four months after FIFA general secretary [Jérôme
Valcke](/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_Valcke "Jérôme Valcke") said the door was
closed on [goal-line technology](/wiki/Goal-line_technology "Goal-line
technology") and video replays after a vote by the
[IFAB](/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board "International Football
Association Board").[78]

### Quarter-finals

The three quarter-finals between European and South American teams all
resulted in wins for Europeans. Germany had a 4–0 victory over Argentina, and
the Netherlands came from behind to beat Brazil 2–1, handing the Brazilians
their first loss in a World Cup match held outside Europe (other than in a
penalty shootout) since [1950](/wiki/Uruguay_v_Brazil_\(1950_FIFA_World_Cup\)
"Uruguay v Brazil \(1950 FIFA World Cup\)") when Uruguay won the decisive
match 2–1.[79] Spain reached the final four for the first time since 1950
after a 1–0 win over Paraguay. Uruguay, the only South American team to reach
the semi-finals, overcame Ghana in a [penalty shoot-
out](/wiki/Penalty_shootout_\(football\) "Penalty shootout \(football\)")
after a 1–1 draw in which Ghana missed a penalty at the end of extra time
after [Luis Suárez](/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez "Luis Suárez") controversially
handled the ball on the line.

Brazil, Italy, Germany or Argentina.

### Final

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup Final](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Final
"2010 FIFA World Cup Final")

The final was held on 11 July 2010 at [Soccer City](/wiki/Soccer_City "Soccer
City"), [Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg").
[Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football team")
defeated the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team
"Netherlands national football team") 1–0, with an extra time goal from
[Andrés Iniesta](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta "Andrés Iniesta"). Iniesta scored
the latest winning goal in a FIFA World Cup final (116').[81] The win gave
Spain their first World Cup title, becoming the eighth team to win it. This
made them the first new winner without home advantage since Brazil in
1958,[82] and the first team to win the tournament after having lost their
opening game.[67]

A large number of fouls were committed in the final match. Referee [Howard
Webb](/wiki/Howard_Webb "Howard Webb") handed out 14 yellow cards, more than
doubling the previous record for this fixture, set when Argentina and West
Germany shared six cards in 1986,[67] and [John Heitinga](/wiki/John_Heitinga
"John Heitinga") of the Netherlands was sent off for receiving a second yellow
card. The Netherlands had chances to score, most notably in the 60th minute
when Arjen Robben was released by [Wesley Sneijder](/wiki/Wesley_Sneijder
"Wesley Sneijder") to be one-on-one with Spain's goalkeeper [Iker
Casillas](/wiki/Iker_Casillas "Iker Casillas"), only for Casillas to save the
shot with an outstretched leg. For Spain, [Sergio Ramos](/wiki/Sergio_Ramos
"Sergio Ramos") missed a free header from a corner kick when he was
unmarked.[83] Iniesta finally broke the deadlock in extra time, scoring a
volleyed shot from a pass by [Cesc Fàbregas](/wiki/Cesc_F%C3%A0bregas "Cesc
Fàbregas").[84]

This result marked the first time that two teams from the same continent had
won successive World Cups (following Italy in 2006), and saw Europe reaching
10 World Cup titles, surpassing South America's nine titles. Spain became the
first team since West Germany in 1974 to win the World Cup as [European
champions](/wiki/UEFA_European_Football_Championship "UEFA European Football
Championship"). The result also marked the first time that a European nation
had won a World Cup Finals that was not hosted on European soil.

A closing ceremony was held before the final, featuring singer
[Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira"). Afterwards, the former South African
President [Nelson Mandela](/wiki/Nelson_Mandela "Nelson Mandela") made a brief
appearance on the pitch, wheeled in by a motorcart.[71][85]

## Statistics

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup
statistics](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_statistics "2010 FIFA World Cup
statistics")

### Goalscorers

For the full list of goalscorers, see [2010 FIFA World Cup statistics §
Goalscorers](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_statistics#Goalscorers "2010 FIFA World
Cup statistics").

South African winger [Siphiwe Tshabalala](/wiki/Siphiwe_Tshabalala "Siphiwe
Tshabalala") was the first player to score a goal in the competition, in their
[1–1 draw against
Mexico](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A#South_Africa_vs_Mexico "2010 FIFA
World Cup Group A"), the opening game of the tournament. Danish defender
[Daniel Agger](/wiki/Daniel_Agger "Daniel Agger") was credited with the first
[own goal](/wiki/Own_goal "Own goal") of the tournament, in his side's [2–0
loss to the
Netherlands](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_E#Netherlands_vs_Denmark "2010
FIFA World Cup Group E"). Argentine striker [Gonzalo
Higuaín](/wiki/Gonzalo_Higua%C3%ADn "Gonzalo Higuaín") was the only player to
score a [hat-trick](/wiki/Hat-trick "Hat-trick") in the tournament, in
Argentina's [4–1 win over South
Korea](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B#Argentina_vs_South_Korea "2010 FIFA
World Cup Group B"). It was the 49th [World Cup hat-
trick](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_hat-tricks "List of FIFA World Cup hat-
tricks") in the history of the tournament.

Spain set a new record for the fewest goals scored by a World Cup-winning
team, with eight.[83] The previous record low was 11, set by Brazil in
[1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup"), England in
[1966](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World Cup"),[83] and Italy in
[1938](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup").[86] Spain had the
fewest goalscorers for a champion as well (three – Villa with five goals,
Iniesta with two and Puyol with one).[67] They also had the fewest goals
conceded for a champion (2), equal with Italy (2006) and France (1998).
Spain's victory marked the first time that a team won the World Cup without
conceding a goal in the knockout stage.[81]

The four top scorers in the tournament had five goals each. All of the four
top scorers also came from the teams that finished in the top four, Spain, the
Netherlands, Germany, and Uruguay. The [Golden
Boot](/wiki/World_Cup_Golden_Boot "World Cup Golden Boot") went to [Thomas
Müller](/wiki/Thomas_M%C3%BCller "Thomas Müller") of Germany who had three
[assists](/wiki/Assist_\(football\) "Assist \(football\)"), compared to one
for the three others. The Silver Boot went to [David Villa](/wiki/David_Villa
"David Villa") of Spain, who played a total of 635 minutes, and the Bronze
Boot to [Wesley Sneijder](/wiki/Wesley_Sneijder "Wesley Sneijder") of the
Netherlands, who played 652 minutes. [Diego Forlán](/wiki/Diego_Forl%C3%A1n
"Diego Forlán") of Uruguay had five goals and one assist in 654 minutes. A
further three players scored four goals.[87]

Only 145 goals were scored at South Africa 2010, the lowest of any FIFA World
Cup since the tournament switched to a 64-game format. This continued a
downward trend since the first 64-game finals were held 12 years earlier, with
171 goals at [France 1998](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup"),
161 at [Korea/Japan 2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") and
147 at [Germany 2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup").[67]

### Discipline

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup disciplinary
record](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_disciplinary_record "2010 FIFA World Cup
disciplinary record")

28 players were suspended after being shown two consecutive yellow cards (13
players), a single red card (8 players), or a yellow card followed by a red
card (7 players).

### Dream Team

For the first time, FIFA did not release an official [All-Star
Team](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#All-Star_Team "FIFA World Cup awards"), but
instead published a Dream Team decided by an online public vote. People were
invited to select a team (in a [4–4–2
formation](/wiki/Formation_\(association_football\)#4–4–2 "Formation
\(association football\)")) and best coach; voting was open until 23:59 on 11
July 2010,[90] with entrants going into a draw to win a prize.

Six of the eleven players came from the Spanish team, as did the coach. The
remainder of the team comprised two players from Germany, and one each from
Brazil, the Netherlands and Uruguay.[91][92]

  * [Goalkeeper](/wiki/Goalkeeper_\(association_football\) "Goalkeeper \(association football\)"): [![Spain](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png)](/wiki/Spain "Spain") [Iker Casillas](/wiki/Iker_Casillas "Iker Casillas") ([Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football team"))

### Mascot

Main article: [Zakumi](/wiki/Zakumi "Zakumi")

The [official mascot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_mascot "FIFA World Cup mascot") for
the 2010 World Cup was _[Zakumi](/wiki/Zakumi "Zakumi")_ , an
[anthropomorphised](/wiki/Anthropomorphic "Anthropomorphic") [African
leopard](/wiki/African_leopard "African leopard") with green hair, presented
on 22 September 2008. His name came from "ZA" (the [international
abbreviation](/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-2 "ISO 3166-1 alpha-2") for South Africa)
and the term _kumi_ , which means "ten" in various [African
languages](/wiki/African_languages "African languages").[93] The mascot's
colours reflected those of the host nation's playing strip – yellow and green.

### Official song

Main article: [FIFA World Cup official
songs](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_official_songs "FIFA World Cup official songs")

The official song of the 2010 World Cup "[Waka
Waka](/wiki/Waka_Waka_\(This_Time_for_Africa\) "Waka Waka \(This Time for
Africa\)")" was performed by the [Colombian](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia") singer
[Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira") and the band
[Freshlyground](/wiki/Freshlyground "Freshlyground") from South Africa, and is
sung in both English and Spanish.[94] The song is based on a traditional
African soldiers' song, "[Zangalewa](/wiki/Zamina_mina_\(Zangalewa\) "Zamina
mina \(Zangalewa\)")".[95] Shakira and Freshlyground performed the song at the
pre-tournament concert in [Soweto](/wiki/Soweto "Soweto") on 10 June. It was
also sung at the [opening ceremony](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_opening_ceremony
"2010 FIFA World Cup opening ceremony") on 11 June and at the closing ceremony
on 11 July. The official anthem of the 2010 World Cup was "[Sign of a
Victory](/wiki/Sign_of_a_Victory "Sign of a Victory")" by [R.
Kelly](/wiki/R._Kelly "R. Kelly") with the Soweto Spiritual Singers, which was
also performed at the opening ceremony.

### Match ball

Main article: [Adidas Jabulani](/wiki/Adidas_Jabulani "Adidas Jabulani")

The match [ball](/wiki/Association_football_\(ball\) "Association football
\(ball\)") for the 2010 World Cup, manufactured by [Adidas](/wiki/Adidas
"Adidas"), was named the _Jabulani_ , which means _" bringing joy to
everyone"_ in [Zulu](/wiki/Zulu_language "Zulu language"). It was the eleventh
World Cup match ball made by the German sports equipment maker; it featured
eleven colours, representing each player of a team on the pitch and the eleven
official [languages of South Africa](/wiki/Languages_of_South_Africa
"Languages of South Africa").[96][97] A special match ball with gold panels,
called the _Jo 'bulani_, was used at the final in
[Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg").

The ball was constructed using a new design, consisting of eight thermally
bonded, three-dimensional panels. These were spherically moulded from
[ethylene-vinyl acetate](/wiki/Ethylene-vinyl_acetate "Ethylene-vinyl
acetate") (EVA) and [thermoplastic
polyurethanes](/wiki/Thermoplastic_polyurethanes "Thermoplastic
polyurethanes") (TPU). The surface of the ball was textured with grooves, a
technology developed by Adidas called GripnGroove[98] that was intended to
improve the ball's aerodynamics. The design received considerable academic
input, being developed in partnership with researchers from [Loughborough
University](/wiki/Loughborough_University "Loughborough University"), United
Kingdom.[99] The balls were made in China, using latex bladders made in India,
thermoplastic polyurethane-elastomer from Taiwan, ethylene vinyl acetate,
isotropic polyester/cotton fabric, and glue and ink from China.[100]

Some football stars complained about the new ball, arguing that its movements
were difficult to predict.[101] Brazilian goalkeeper [Júlio
César](/wiki/J%C3%BAlio_C%C3%A9sar_\(football_goalkeeper,_born_1979\) "Júlio
César \(football goalkeeper, born 1979\)") compared it to a "supermarket" ball
that favored strikers and worked against goalkeepers.[102] Argentinian coach
[Diego Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego Maradona") said: "We won't see
any long passes in this World Cup because the ball doesn't fly straight."[103]
However, a number of Adidas-sponsored[104][105][106] players responded
favourably to the ball.

### Vuvuzelas

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg/220px-
Vuvuzela_blower%2C_Final_Draw%2C_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vuvuzela_blower,_Final_Draw,_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vuvuzela_blower,_Final_Draw,_FIFA_2010_World_Cup.jpg "Enlarge")

A man sounding a vuvuzela

Main article: [Vuvuzela](/wiki/Vuvuzela "Vuvuzela")

The 2010 finals amplified international public awareness of the
[vuvuzela](/wiki/Vuvuzela "Vuvuzela"), a long horn blown by fans throughout
matches.[107][108][109][110] Many World Cup competitors complained about the
noise caused by the vuvuzela horns, including France's [Patrice
Evra](/wiki/Patrice_Evra "Patrice Evra"), who blamed the horns for the team's
poor performance.[111] Other critics include [Lionel Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi
"Lionel Messi"), who complained that the sound of the vuvuzelas hampers
communication among players on the pitch,[112] and broadcasting companies,
which complained that commentators' voices were being drowned out by the
sound.[113]

Others watching on television complained that the ambient audio feed from the
stadium only contains the sounds of the vuvuzelas and the natural sounds of
people in the stands are drowned out.[114][115] A spokesperson for
[ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") and other networks said that they were taking steps
to minimise the ambient noise on their broadcasts.[116] The [BBC](/wiki/BBC
"BBC") also investigated the possibility of offering broadcasts without
vuvuzela noise.[117]

## Event effects

Cola_aeroplane.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy_Tour_Coca-Cola_aeroplane.jpg "Enlarge")

A FIFA World Cup Trophy Tour aeroplane, sponsored by [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-
Cola "Coca-Cola"). (2010)

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup event
effects](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_event_effects "2010 FIFA World Cup event
effects")

### Social

Tournament organiser [Danny Jordaan](/wiki/Danny_Jordaan "Danny Jordaan")
dismissed concerns that the [attack on the Togo national
team](/wiki/Togo_national_football_team_bus_attack "Togo national football
team bus attack") which took place in [Angola](/wiki/Angola "Angola") in
January 2010, had any relevance to the security arrangements for the World
Cup.[148] There were also reports of thefts against visitors to the country
for the World Cup. Tourists from China, Portugal, Spain, South Korea, Japan
and [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia") had become victims of crime.[149] On
19 June after the match between England and Algeria, a fan was able to break
through the FIFA-appointed security staff at Green Point stadium and gain
access to the England team dressing room. The breach took place shortly after
[Prince William](/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cambridge "Prince William, Duke
of Cambridge") and [Prince Harry](/wiki/Prince_Harry "Prince Harry") had left
the room. The trespasser was then released before he could be handed over to
the Police. [English FA](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football
Association") lodged a formal complaint with FIFA and demanded that security
be increased.[150]

#### Resettlement and eviction

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG/220px-2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG)](/wiki/File:2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:2009Blikkiesdorp.JPG "Enlarge")

Police patrol Blikkiesdorp, a settlement for the evicted.

As with many 'hallmark events' throughout the world,[151] the 2010 FIFA World
Cup has been connected to [evictions](/wiki/Eviction
"Eviction"),[152][153][154][155][156] which many claim are meant to 'beautify
the city', impress visiting tourists, and hide shackdwellers. On 14 May 2009,
the Durban-based shack-dwellers' movement [Abahlali
baseMjondolo](/wiki/Abahlali_baseMjondolo "Abahlali baseMjondolo") took the
KwaZulu-Natal government to court over their controversial [Elimination and
Prevention of Re-Emergence of Slums
Act](/wiki/Elimination_and_Prevention_of_Re-Emergence_of_Slums_Act
"Elimination and Prevention of Re-Emergence of Slums Act"), meant to eliminate
slums in South Africa and put homeless shackdwellers in transit camps in time
for the 2010 World Cup.[157][158]

Another prominent controversy surrounding preparations for the World Cup was
the [N2 Gateway](/wiki/N2_Gateway "N2 Gateway") housing project in [Cape
Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), which planned to remove over 20,000
residents from the [Joe Slovo Informal
Settlement](/wiki/Joe_Slovo_Informal_Settlement "Joe Slovo Informal
Settlement") along the busy N2 Freeway and build rental flats and bond-houses
in its place in time for the 2010 World Cup.[159] NGOs, international human
rights organisations, and the [Anti-Eviction Campaign](/wiki/Anti-
Eviction_Campaign "Anti-Eviction Campaign") have publicly criticised the
conditions in [Blikkiesdorp](/wiki/Blikkiesdorp "Blikkiesdorp") and said that
the camp has been used to accommodate poor families evicted to make way for
the 2010 World Cup.[156][160][161][162]

However some have argued that evictions are ordinarily common in South Africa
and that in the lead up to the tournament many evictions were erreonously
ascribed to the World Cup.[163]

### Economy

Some groups experienced complications in regards to scheduled sporting events,
advertising, or broadcasting, as FIFA attempted to maximise control of media
rights during the Cup. Affected parties included an international [rugby
union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") [Test
match](/wiki/Test_match_\(rugby_union\) "Test match \(rugby union\)"), a South
African airline, and some TV networks, all of whom were involved in various
legal struggles with World Cup organisers.[164][165][166]

During the tournament, group ticket-holders who did not utilise all their
allotted tickets led to some early-round matches having as many as 11,000
unoccupied seats.[167]

While the event did help to boost the image of South Africa, financially it
turned out to be a major disappointment.[168] Construction costs for venues
and infrastructure amounted to £3 billion (€3.6 billion), and the government
expected that increased tourism would help to offset these costs to the amount
of £570 million (€680 million). However, only £323 million (€385 million) were
actually taken in as 309,000 foreign fans came to South Africa, well below the
expected number of 450,000.[168]

Local vendors were prohibited from selling food and merchandise within a 1.5
kilometre radius of any stadium hosting a World Cup match. For a vendor to
operate within the radius, a registration fee of [R](/wiki/South_African_rand
"South African rand")60,000 (approximately to US$7,888 or €6,200), had to be
paid to [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA"). This fee was out of most local vendors'
reach, as they are simple one-man-operated vendors. This prevented
international visitors from experiencing local South African food. Some local
vendors felt cheated out of an opportunity for financial gain and spreading
South African culture, in favour of multinational corporations.[169]

FIFA president Sepp Blatter declared the event "a huge financial success for
everybody, for Africa, for South Africa and for FIFA," with revenue to FIFA of
£2.24 billion (€2 billion).[170]

### Quality

In a December 2010 _Quality Progress_ , FIFA President Blatter rated South
Africa's organisational efforts a nine out of 10 scale, declaring that South
Africa could be considered a plan B for all future competitions. The South
African Quality Institute (SAQI) assisted in facility construction, event
promotion, and organisations. The main issue listed in the article was lack of
sufficient public transportation.[171]

## Media

### Broadcasting

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup broadcasting
rights](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_broadcasting_rights "2010 FIFA World Cup
broadcasting rights")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg/220px-
Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg)](/wiki/File:Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Production_set_of_the_2010_FIFA_World_Cup.jpg "Enlarge")

Production set of the FIFA international broadcast centre during the event

The 2010 FIFA World Cup was expected to be the most-watched television event
in history.[172] Hundreds of broadcasters, representing about 70 countries,
transmitted the Cup to a TV audience that FIFA officials expect to exceed a
cumulative 26 billion people, an average of approximately 400 million viewers
per match. FIFA estimated that around 700 million viewers would watch the
[World Cup final](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2010 FIFA World Cup
Final").[173]

New forms of digital media have also allowed viewers to watch coverage through
alternative means. "With games airing live on cell phones and computers, the
World Cup will get more online coverage than any major sporting event yet,"
said Jake Coyle of the [Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated
Press").[174]

In the United States, [ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American
Broadcasting Company"), [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") and [ESPN2](/wiki/ESPN2
"ESPN2") averaged a 2.1 rating, 2,288,000 households and 3,261,000 viewers for
the 64 World Cup games. The rating was up 31 percent from a 1.6 in 2006, while
households increased 32 percent from 1,735,000 and viewers rose from
2,316,000. The increases had been higher while the US remained in the
tournament. Through the first 50 games, the rating was up 48 percent,
households increased 54 percent and viewers rose 60 percent.
[Univision](/wiki/Univision "Univision") averaged 2,624,000 viewers for the
tournament, up 17 percent, and 1,625,000 households, an increase of 11
percent.[175] An executive of the [Nielsen Company](/wiki/Nielsen_Company
"Nielsen Company"), a leading audience research firm in the US, described the
aggregate numbers for both networks' coverage of the USA-Ghana match as
"phenomenal".[176] Live World Cup streaming on [ESPN3.com](/wiki/ESPN3
"ESPN3") pulled in some of the largest audiences in history, as 7.4 million
unique viewers tuned in for matches. In total, ESPN3.com generated 942 million
minutes of viewing or more than two hours per unique viewer. All 64 live
matches were viewed by an average of 114,000 persons per minute. Most
impressive were the numbers for the semi-final between Spain and Germany,
which was viewed by 355,000 people per minute, making it ESPN3.com's largest
average audience ever.[177]

### Filming

Sony technology was used to film the tournament. 25 of the matches were
captured using 3D cameras.[178] Footage was captured in 3D through Sony's
proprietary multi-image MPE-200 processors, housed in specially designed 3D
outside broadcast trucks.[179] It supplied its flagship HDC-1500 cameras as
well as its new HDC-P1 unit, a compact, point-of-view (POV)-type camera with
3, 2/3-inch CCD sensors.[180] The 3D games were produced for FIFA by Host
Broadcast Services.[181]

### Video games

In [PlayStation Home](/wiki/PlayStation_Home "PlayStation Home"),
[Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony") has released a [virtual
space](/wiki/List_of_PlayStation_Home_Game_Spaces#Non-gaming_Company_Spaces
"List of PlayStation Home Game Spaces") based on the 2010 FIFA World Cup in
the Japanese version of Home on 3 December 2009. This virtual space is called
the "FevaArena" and is a virtual stadium of the 2010 FIFA World Cup, featuring
different areas for events, a FIFA mini-game, and a shop with FIFA related
content.[182]

On 27 April 2010, [EA Sports](/wiki/EA_Sports "EA Sports") released the
official [2010 World Cup video
game](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_South_Africa_\(video_game\) "2010 FIFA World
Cup South Africa \(video game\)").[183]

### FIFA Fan Fest

FIFA expanded the [FIFA Fan Fest](/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Fest "FIFA Fan Fest"),
hosting in [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), [Buenos Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires
"Buenos Aires"), [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris
"Paris"), [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"), [Rio de
Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_\(city\) "Rio de Janeiro \(city\)") and [Mexico
City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City"), as well as several venues around South
Africa.[184] The Durban Fan Fest was the most popular in South Africa during
the tournament followed by the [Cape Town Fan
Fest](/wiki/World_Cup_2010_FIFA_Fan_Fest_in_Cape_Town "World Cup 2010 FIFA Fan
Fest in Cape Town").[185]
